poem:
**Invisible Frameworks**

Morning's paper spills  
with talk of orthodoxy,  
an economic dew draped  
on the grass of thought.

Rachel's duty to the people,  
a thread unwoven from the loom  
of markets and Thatcher's ghost,  
while new patterns  
hide in plain sight—  
spring seeds pushing through  
cracks in old stone.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Rachel Reeves’s duty is to the people, not the markets | Letters Your editorial (14 January) rightly critiques Rachel Reeves’s adherence to Treasury orthodoxy. But the persistence of this framework goes deeper than institutional inertia. It reflects a failure to recognise a choice at all – and an inability to imagine and craft better alternatives. Treasury orthodoxy is rooted in the Thatcher-Reagan era. It is not just outdated, but has become invisible to those who". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
